Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Technology to predict power generation and optimize energy storage in cities
Award.AbstractNarration: The broader impacts/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is to explore technology to synchronize different sources of energy for buildings. The stakeholders include utility, independent system operators, energy analyst, building automation providers, energy aggregators, energy regulators and third-party energy providers. The project will investigate how software predicting the efficiency and configurations of solar cell installations can improve their performance.<br/><br/>This I-Corps project technology is based on the development of a modified numerical weather prediction modeling system (WRF). This system will allow designers to optimize active technologies, such as photovoltaic (PV) installations on the roofs of buildings, and passive systems such as efficiency enhancement, insulation and white roofs, to meet and minimize the electricity demand. These technologies are developed not only to mitigate extreme loads but also to provide and forecast PV-power potential. This system can be used on-site or at a utility to promote integration of energy sources such as solar PV, electro-thermal batteries, and micro-grids, and to optimize demand response strategies.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The landscape of building energy management is rapidly changing due to the penetration of renewable and/or low carbon technologies. The traditional energy demand response market is responsive to local demands to reduce risks of peak loads which will typically lead to higher rates and large operational costs.  Most typical cases are during summer seasons where peak building energy demand events occur more often, leading to penalties.  Institutional buildings such as universities, hospitals, corporate campuses, grocery stores, and government offices are particularly susceptible to these costs due to their large occupancy rates as well as numerous large buildings.  

Under this NSF I-CORPS project, a team of students and faculty explored the market value of energy forecasting with renewable tools for demand response markets. 

Through a market discovery effort where more than 100 companies in US and abroad were contacted and interviewed, a deep understanding of the changing conditions on the demand response markets was possible.  The team narrowed the market value proposition of energy forecasts with on-site renewable generation and storage to a reliable product for building operators, building managers, and energy planners in demand response markets located in large cities.  The market value proposition of forecasting both demand and potential renewable energy generation with storage needs was -in general- received positively by the potential customers.  The market size for improved building energy management is estimated in more $20B and growing very rapidly. It was confirmed that the market need is for a reliable and low cost energy forecast solution at the individual buildings and/or campus with future window of 24 hrs or longer. 

The team further developed and tested a system to forecast energy demands and on-site renewable energy generation up to 72 hrs in advance with no required hardware installation. The developed system forecasts both energy demands and potential solar energy production days ahead for single buildings, neighborhood and cities. These energy forecasts are obtained through novel use of high resolution weather models adapted to consider the interaction between the thermal and mechanical effects of the urban environment taking into account the anthropogenic heat contributions due to indoor-outdoor energy and mass exchanges.  The new product includes building integrated solar PV providing information of potential on-site solar PV generation to meet the energy demands including needs for energy storage when generation does not meet demand.  As a result, it is possible to predict, at a single instance and without reliance of on-site installed instruments, the weather, energy demands, renewable energy generation, and needs for energy storage (in W/m2 or kWh) for a single building, an entire neighborhood or a city.  This is more effective in cities where weather is a major driver of the peak demands (i.e. large loads due to heating, ventilation, and air conditioning, [HVAC]). The information is provided at temporal resolutions that can vary from minutes to days, and spatial resolutions from few meters to a few kilometers in 2D or 3D. Preliminary testing of this method in New York City was successful when benchmarking results with a large number of environmental sensors across the city and a few selected buildings.  This technology approach could empower buildings facilities managers to optimize their resources, allowing them to better manage manpower and resources to handle peak loads including the possibility of "getting off the grid" whenever they expect increased costs due to peak demand events. 

With worldwide demand response programs increasing, the continued trend in warmer summers inducing higher demand peaks, and the rapid penetration of renewables to meet these energy demands, this I-CORPS project opened the opportunities to support stakeholders to reduce their operational costs with minimal onsite footprint.  The prospect technical solution has the ability to serve any building in any given city allowing to scale fast and with few technical barriers taking advantage of the growing need for energy management at the building level.
